Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 39260  
November 2005  
 
 
Technical Assistance  
Asian Development Outlook 2006
  
 
Prepared by [Author(s)] 
[Firm] 
[Address] 
 
Prepared for  [Executing Agency] 
    [Implementing Agency] 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADO  –  Asian Development Outlook 
  DER  –  Department of External Relations 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  ERMF  –  Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division 
  RD  –  regional department 
  RM  –  resident mission 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  TASU  –  TA supervising unit 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Theme  –  Sustainable economic growth 
Subtheme  –  Promoting macroeconomic stability  
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice President  G.H.P.B. van der Linden, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development Group 
Director General  I. Ali, Chief Economist, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Director  F. J. Harrigan, Assistant Chief Economist, ERD 
   
Team leader  C. Castillo, Senior Statistics Officer, ERD 
Team member  E. Laviña, Economics Officer, ERD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  To provide relevant information and analysis, to contribute to the intellectual environment 
in which policy formulation occurs, and to maintain and enhance its reputation as a credible and 
authoritative  source  of  knowledge  about  the  region,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
regularly  monitors  and  offers  commentary  about  evolving  developments  in  its  developing 
member countries (DMCs). The Asian Development Outlook1 (ADO) is the principal vehicle for 
the delivery of these services region wide.   ADO content also informs Management opinion and 
guides institutional views about prospective developments and other important issues. The ADO 
has  been  a  flagship  publication  of  ADB  since  1989.    The  preparation,  publication,  and 
dissemination of the ADO have been regularly supported by technical assistance (TA) funding.  
Appendix 1 sets out the objectives, scope, and activities to be covered by the proposed regional 
TA2.   
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Ongoing efforts to improve the quality of the ADO are focused on providing stronger 
analytical content and ensuring better cohesion and balance among its different parts. These 
initiatives respond to feedback from clients and to a changing environment and market for 
economic information and analysis. Efforts to improve the quality of analysis will include (i) 
commissioning  of  relevant  applied  and  policy  research  at  country  and  regional  levels;  (ii) 
increased application of appropriate modeling and other analytical tools; (iii) development of 
new  sources  of  information;  and  (iv)  improvement  of  peer  review,  drawing  on  in-country 
expertise. In an increasingly competitive market for knowledge and information, high-quality 
editing services are critical to ensure that ADO’s key messages are communicated as effectively 
as possible.  The Economics and Research Department (ERD) will continue to work with the 
Department of External Relations (DER) to increase ADO’s regional and international reach.   
 
3.  The rational for the TA is to support activities that will contribute to high-quality content 
and help ensure the usefulness and relevance of the ADO to policy discussions and formulation. 
Currently, the ADO is the most frequently downloaded publication from ADB’s website and is 
directly  or  indirectly  the  source  of  much  international  and  national  news  commentary  that 
features analysis, views, and opinions from ADB.  Elevating ADO’s profile further and widening 
its influence will require a concerted effort, not just to improve quality but to differentiate content. 
  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
4.  The main outputs from the TA will be ADO 2006 and ADO 2006 Update. Activities 
supported under the TA will also feed into the preparation of subsequent years’ ADOs.  Draft 
contents pages of ADO 2006 and ADO 2006 Update are in Appendix 2.   The major thematic 
focus in 2006 will have three pillars linked to issues of trade integration and liberalization: (i) 
behind-the-border impediments to trade within developing Asia and between developing Asia 
and the rest of the world; (ii) developing Asia’s evolving interests in the Doha Round (post Hong 
                                                 
1 ADO is sold externally and is extensively reviewed and commented on in the media. It is also the most popular 
document on the ADB website. 
2 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 17 June 2005.

2   
Kong, China); and (iii) impact of the cessation of the Multi-Fiber Arrangement on developing 
Asia.  It is expected that one or more of these issues will feature in most country chapters as 
well as be covered at a regional and subregional level in parts 1 and 3.   Depending on future 
developments,  ADO  2006  may  also  provide  a  more  substantial  analysis  of  the  possible 
consequence of an Avian flu pandemic for developing Asia. 
 
5.  The  TA  will  further  develop  economic  forecasting  and  policy  analysis  models  and 
techniques in support of ADB’s short- and medium-term country economic analysis. The models 
will be used to generate short- and medium-term economic forecasts in the country chapter of 
ADO 2006 and ADO 2006 Update, as well as to strengthen the economic underpinnings of 
country programs and strategies for the DMCs covered. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The key activities to be supported by the TA will include (i) preparation of background 
analytical papers, (ii) further development and refinement of empirical projection methods and 
other analytical tools, (iii) drafting of ADO content, (iv) economic and copy editing, and (v) 
preparation  and  layout  of  materials  for  publication.  In  addition,  the  TA  will  finance  the 
procurement of information and knowledge services that may be required to support high-quality 
and up-to-date content; and support workshops, seminars and training activities that are directly 
relevant to the preparation and strengthening of the ADO.   
 
7.  The terms of reference for the background analytical papers will be prepared by the 
Macroeconomics  and  Finance  Research  Division  (ERMF)  in  consultation  with  operational 
departments, as relevant.   The objective of these papers will be to nurture substantive ADO 
content.   On a case-by-case basis, resources will be provided to resident missions (RMs) to 
prepare country background papers on areas of agreed-upon thematic focus. 
 
8.  The TA will support the continued use of quantitative tools for economic analysis and 
forecasting. Key activities will include support for consultants and resource persons to maintain 
and update databases, to reestimate model equations (as required), and to further develop and 
apply automatic leading indicators.    
 
9.  Economic and copy editing activity will be provided by consultants working under the 
direction of the assistant chief economist, ERMF.   High-quality editing services are crucial to 
ensure cohesion of content and consistency in approach across the different chapters and parts 
of the ADO. 
 
10.  Training  activities  will  focus  on  extending  knowledge  of  statistical  methods  and 
databases, economic projection methods and other relevant skills.  As appropriate, training will 
target economists in operations departments, national officers in resident missions (RMs), and, 
as appropriate, government officials and other client groups. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $340,000 (Appendix 3). The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program.

3
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB will be the Executing Agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA.  
In particular, ERMF will implement the TA in close collaboration with regional departments (East 
and Central Asia, Southeast Asia, South Asia, Mekong, and Pacific), and RMs.   The assistant 
chief  economist,  ERMF,  reporting  to  the  chief  economist,  ERD,  will  be  responsible  for 
implementation. At each step in the preparation of the ADO, ERD will report to the Vice-
President, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development Group and to the President.   
 
13.  Developing analytical approaches and tools to support high-quality ADO content will 
be  a  collaborative  effort  involving  ERMF  economists,  country  economists  of  the  regional 
departments  (RDs)  and  RMs,  national  experts,  international  consultants  and  high-quality 
economics editors. The TA will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services 
that may be required to support high-quality and up-to-date content. Procurement will be done in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. The TA is expected to start in December 
2005 and to be completed by December 2006. 
 
14.  The ADO training workshop for the country chapter writers on macroeconomics and 
economic projections is tentatively scheduled for November 2006 at ADB headquarters.   The 
number of participants will be limited to maximize quality interaction.  The possibility of a second 
conference on the use of modeling methods will also be considered. 
 
15.  For ADO 2006 and ADO 2006 Update, it is estimated that 150 consultancy days for 
domestic consultants will be required to help prepare the thematic content.  Appendix 4 gives 
the outline terms of reference for the macroeconomic and thematic specialists. In addition, the 
ADO will require 4 person-months of international consultancy resources for the preparation of 
thematic  chapters  and  background  papers.    Another  7  person-months  of  international 
consultants’ time will be required for economic and technical editing of ADO manuscripts before 
final publication. The consultants will be hired as individuals. Resource persons will also be 
engaged to conduct training workshops and prepare background papers on economic trends in 
and  prospects  of  selected  DMCs.  Terms  of  reference  for  these  consultants  and  resource 
persons are attached.  ADB will engage the consultants and resource persons in accordance 
with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for 
engaging domestic consultants.  
 
16.  ADB staff will disseminate the major results of ADO 2006 and ADO 2006 Update to the 
media, DMC policy makers, and civil society. The TA will support translation of the ADO into 
Chinese  and  Russian  languages  to  extend  its  audience  in  selected  DMCs.    This  will  be 
arranged by RDs in consultation with the concerned RMs. The dissemination activities will be 
coordinated by DER in cooperation with ERMF. In selected DMCs, the RMs will undertake 
separate launches and will be supported by ERMF. Both ADO 2006 and ADO 2006 Update will 
be featured on the ADB website and printed copies will be distributed worldwide. In countries 
where broadband access is limited, CD-ROMs will be made available through the RMs. ERMF 
will work with DER to attempt to capture broader and more useful client feedback.   This activity 
may require some limited TA resources.  ERMF will circulate internally a report on the outcome 
of the automatic leading indicators modeling exercises with proposals on how to build on this TA 
for future issues of the ADO and in possible applications of the macroeconometric models in 
country work.

4   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $340,000 on a grant basis for 
the Asian Development Outlook 2006, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 2 
DRAFT CONTENTS OF ADO 2006 AND ADO 2006 UPDATE

The Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division will propose changes in coverage and 
content to be considered by Management.

Appendix 4  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Economic Consultants 
1.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general macroeconomics 
and good knowledge of the developing member country (DMC) economy. Under the direct 
supervision of the assistant chief economist, Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division 
(ERMF), the consultants will 
 
(i)  prepare thematic chapters, background papers, and country reports as may be 
assigned; 
(ii)  work with the economics editor to ensure consistency and coherence of the 
Asian Development Outlook (ADO) publication; and 
(iii)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist, ERMF. 
 
B.  International Economics Editor 
2.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF and in consultation 
with other Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff in the Economics and Research Department 
(ERD) involved in preparing and reviewing the country chapters in Asian Development Outlook 
(ADO) 2006 and ADO 2006 Update, the economics editor will edit the manuscripts for consistency 
and economic content. The editor will assist in preparing the highlights (English version) of the 
publication. The editor will ensure that all the data in the publication is based on the most recent 
information available as of the specified cut-off date.  
 
3.  In particular, the economics editor will 
 
(i)  edit ADO for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical evidence; 
(ii)  edit ADO for internal consistency; 
(iii)   edit ADO for balanced coverage and degree of detail and precision; 
(iv)   check the report for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to  
  the prescribed requirements for ADO; 
(v)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the  
  write-up; 
(vi)  confer with ERMF staff regarding gaps in the write-up, important questions, and  
  needed revisions; 
(vii)  assist in preparing the publication highlights; 
(viii)  help prepare the key messages and review press releases for ADO; and 
(ix)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by the 
assistant chief economist, ERMF. 
 
C.  International Copy Editor-cum-Desktop Publishing Specialist 
4.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF, and in consultation 
with the ADO production coordinator, the copy editor will (i) edit ADO 2006/ADO 2006 Update in 
accordance with ADB’s editorial style; (ii) be responsible for typesetting and proofreading the text, 
tables, and charts of the publication from the preliminary draft to the final copy and filming the 
output before forwarding it to the external printer; (iii) be responsible for data linking to ensure data 
integrity and consistency in the final manuscript; and (iv) be responsible for converting the desktop 
file into portable document format (pdf) and hyper text markup language (html) files for uploading

12  Appendix 4 
 
on the ADB website. The copy editor must have full working knowledge of MSOffice (MSWord 
and MSExcel), Adobe Pagemaker/InDesign, and Corel Draw/Illustrator. 
 
5.  In particular, the copy editor cum desktop publishing specialist will 
   
(i)  edit ADO in conformity with ADB’s editorial style and usage; 
(ii)  edit ADO for consistency and accuracy; 
(iii)  edit the publication summary of ADO; 
(iv)  supervise the encoding of corrections as well as incorporation of tables, charts,  
and boxes; 
(v)  edit ADO for balance (in terms of layout); 
(vi)  review the final manuscript for filming; 
(vii)  prepare the abbreviations list, glossary, and list of references; 
(viii)  edit all dissemination materials including press releases, speeches, questions 
and answers, key messages, and presentation slides; and 
(ix)  convert desktop files to pdf and html formats; and perform all other functions and 
responsibilities as may be assigned by the assistant chief economist, ERMF. 
 
D.  Resource Persons 
6.  The resource persons should have excellent working experience in macroeconometric 
modeling and economic projections.  In particular, the resource persons will 
 
(i)  provide materials for the training workshop; and 
(ii)  conduct  a  1-day  training  workshop  on  macroeconomics  and  economic 
projections at ADB headquarters. 
 
7.  Resource persons from selected DMCs will also be engaged to 
 
(i)  prepare draft background papers on selected thematic issues as they pertain to 
individual DMCs, under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist, 
ERMF; and 
(ii)  update the ADO data sheet. 
 
E.  Domestic Modeling Consultants 
8.  The  consultants  should  have  excellent  working  experience  in  macroeconometric 
modeling  and  good  knowledge  of  the  DMC  economy.  Under  the direct  supervision  of  the 
assistant chief economist, ERMF, the consultants will 
 
(i)  develop a small-scale macroeconometric model of the selected DMC using 
quarterly data, and test the model for robustness in economic structure as well as 
parameter estimates. The model should generate sensible policy simulation 
results; 
(ii)  prepare a summary report of the model specifications, residual analysis, test 
results, and performance evaluation; 
(iii)  design and develop a database system to support the model; document the 
sources and definitions of variables contained in the database; develop a data 
updating routine; and 
(iv)  work with the ADB staff on the tests of the model and on an outline for future 
expansion of the model to be used by ADB.
